Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: In this project Columbus State University is developing the Columbus Region Academy of Future Teachers of STEM (CRAFT-STEM). Elements of the project include a summer STEM Honors camp experience for high-school students, internships for first- and second-year students, Robert Noyce scholarships for 19 juniors and seniors majoring in STEM who are preparing to teach secondary school science or mathematics, and a Teaching Connection Seminar, which encourages preservice teachers to identify links between their STEM major and topics they expect to teach in their future classrooms. The program dovetails with existing resources for outreach, including a regional mathematics collaborative, an environmental learning center, and a space science center. On-campus academic support is available through the Math and Science Learning Center, and the State of Georgia has designated Columbus State University as one of 6 recipients of funding in its STEM II initiative. The science camp and the Teaching Connection Seminar are unique features of this project, which expects to quadruple the number of trained STEM teachers to serve an area of high need. Located near Fort Benning, the project also recruits students from among military dependents and retirees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Columbus Region Academy of Future Teachers of STEM (CRAFT-STEM) program is a Phase I Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (award number 1136356) in which investigators at Columbus State University used summer STEM Honors Camp experiences for middle school and high school students, internships for university freshmen and sophomores, scholarships for university juniors and seniors, and a new Teaching Connections Seminar for pre-service teachers to recruit, develop, and graduate more secondary math and science teachers from the UTeach Columbus program committed to serving high need schools.  The funding period for CRAFT-STEM was from September 1, 2011 through August 31, 2018.

     Summer camp experiences were designed to influence the 6th through 12th grade students who participated and the CRAFT-STEM interns who helped conduct the camp activities. The 6th ? 12th grade students had the chance to nurture and enhance their demonstrated interests in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) through engaging, hands-on learning experiences. These experiences stressed active, hands-on learning rather than rote book learning. Investigators expected interns to increase their interest in teaching careers as they enjoyed the opportunity to lead fun, active learning experiences mentored by experienced university faculty.

     CRAFT-STEM internships were designed to dovetail with a substantial scholarship program that provided $10,000-$14,500 per year for up to two years for juniors and seniors who committed to complete a qualifying math/science major, obtain secondary teaching certification, and teach two years in a high-need school district for each year of scholarship support received. These Noyce scholars also agreed to participate in the Teaching Connections Seminar, which was designed to support their development as teachers with strong content knowledge and preparation to teach in high need schools.

     The STEM Honors Camp and the Teaching Connections Seminar were unique aspects of this Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program and contributed to its intellectual merit. Investigators found that 81.8% of camp participants who responded (99/121) indicated their enthusiasm for STEM had increased as a result of participating in the camp, and that 72.7% of those who responded (40/55) in a survey administered for 2 years) indicated that participation in the STEM camp had influenced their college or career plans.

     Participation in the internship program had a positive influence on interns? consideration of teaching as a career path. In post-internship surveys, 24/29 respondents (83%) indicated they were more interested in teaching as a result of the experience. A total of 10/47 interns (21%) enrolled in a UTeach course after beginning an internship, with 4 of them later receiving Noyce scholarships.

     Participation in the UTeach Columbus and CRAFT-STEM programs appears to have had a positive influence on students? preparation as future teachers. In an annual survey, Noyce scholars were asked to rate the benefits of the Connections Seminar on a 1-10 scale (1 = no benefit, 10 = very beneficial); 23/24 responses assigned a rating of 7 or higher, with 18 ratings of 9 or 10.

     Project investigators also conducted a qualitative study of Noyce scholarship recipients to better understand the influence of the scholarship program on students? consideration of teaching careers with support of program funds. The findings, published in the journal Georgia Education Researcher, suggest the scholarship was not highly effective as a tool for recruiting pre-service teachers, but the financial support enabled students to devote more time to their studies instead of working to support their education, which may improve student learning and program completion.

     The CRAFT-STEM program did achieve a number of broader impacts. More than 150 middle school and high school students benefitted from the summer camp experiences facilitated by program interns; at least 89 camp participants attended high-need schools. Descriptions of the STEM Honors Camp model have been disseminated in regional and national professional meetings. A total of 50 internships were awarded to 47 different students, exceeding the original goal to award 47 total internships. The program awarded 50 one-year scholarships to 32 different students, exceeding the original goal to award 49 scholarships. The year before CRAFT-STEM began, the university had 3 undergraduates earn baccalaureate degrees in STEM majors and teaching certification. Since the program began, CSU has graduated annually an average of 6 STEM majors with teaching certification.
